qas.question: What is one of the issues with affirmative action?
How do people who are in favor of affirmative action view it?

answers.text: an effort towards inclusion rather than a discriminatory practice

qas.question: What does affirmative action supposedly aim to do?
What do proponents of affirmative action believe is the best way to combat exclusionary practices?
What is one of the issues with non-affirmative action?
How do people who aren't in favor of affirmative action view it?
What does affirmative action supposedly not aim to do?
What do proponents of affirmative action believe is the worst way to combat exclusionary practices?

context: Proponents of affirmative action recognize that the policy is <a0_0><b4_0>inherently unequal<b4_0/><a0_0/>; however, minding the inescapable fact that historic inequalities exist in America, they believe the policy is much more fair than one in which these circumstances are not taken into account. Furthermore, those in favor of affirmative action see it as <a1_0>an <b5_0>effort towards inclusion<b5_0/> rather than a discriminatory practice<a1_0/>. "Job discrimination is grounded in prejudice and exclusion, whereas affirmative action is an effort to <a2_0><b6_0>overcome prejudicial treatment through inclusion<b6_0/><a2_0/>. The most effective way to cure society of exclusionary practices is to <a3_0><b7_0>make special efforts at inclusion<b7_0/><a3_0/>, which is exactly what affirmative action does."
